g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute

PPCA and has committed to phaseout unabated coal by 2038. As part of its commitment to phase out
coal, Germany is implementing a set of measures that include compensation for power plant closures,
or coal workers, and substantial support of structural change in coal
transition for workers are important to gain broad public support and help those most affected by the
Coal use has been declining in North America. In the U.S., the primary driver has
been the availability of cheap shale gas and ageing coal fleets. Coal use in the US has dropped by over
50% since 2008 (EIA 2019). The recently announced NDC by the Biden Adm
, indicating a phaseout not only of
unabated coal electricity generation, but also of natural gas generatio
n. As one of the two founding
countries of the PPCA, Canada has committed to phasing out unabated coal power by 2030
. Declining coal use in both the U.S. and Canada has decreased GHG
emissions, local air pollutants, and cooling water use
there have been concerns about social and economic consequences, particularly at the local level. For
instance, the U.S. has lost about 50,000 coal mining jobs between 2011 and 2021 (U.S. Bureau of Labor
cs, 2021), with significant regional and economic inequities
. Comprehensive social programs, such as retirement compensation, training for
t for economic diversification, have been suggested as means to
(Patrizio et al. 2018; Homagain et al. 2015; Grubert 2020)
After a period of rapid growth, coal expansion has slowed in Asia, but it still the primary driver
of the global increase in coal demand
China's coal consumption reached a plateau under
2020), and new coal plants are being built at a slower
rate than previously. Both China and India have suspended and cancelled many new coal power projects
and retired a small set of old, dirty, inefficie
. These efforts are largely due to non
climate reasons, such air pollution and health
Rao 2015; Gass et al. 2016; Peng et al. 2018; Malik et al. 2020)
, and rural electrification and renewable investments
However, as new builds offset retirements, coal generation capacity has continued to grow in both
as Indonesia, Vietnam, and Philippines have experienced strong growth in coal
2020b), but an increasing number of new coal power projects are being cancelled (Littl
are decreasingly likely to proceed because they rely on international
countries have pledged to end overseas coal
: New coal power projects in Africa have been declining since 2016, with only South Africa and
Zimbabwe currently building new coal plants and several others has planned projects (
). However, these projects also largely depend
on international financing and are thus less likely
to be implemented (see above). In South Africa, employment in the coal mining sector has dropped by
almost half since the 1980s and is has been estimated to fall from 77,00 today to 22,000 to 42,000 by
. Policy and financial support are essential to ensure a sustainable
